ygData.subject: Re: NotExceedsDocumentLengthTresholdDecideRule
ygData.msgSnippet: If the content-length is incorrect, the best you can do is set the maxLengthBytes setting on the FetchHTTP processor. Once this limit is hit, the processor

If the content-length is incorrect, the best you can do is set the "maxLeng=
thBytes" setting on the FetchHTTP processor. Once this limit is hit, the pr=
ocessor will stop downloading a file and a truncated file will be written t=
o your archive (unless you have filters on the W(ARC)WriterProcessor to pre=
vent this).

- Kris

--- In archive-crawler@yahoogroups.com, Mohamed Elsaye=
d <mohammed.elsayyed@...> wrote:
>
> Thanks very much for your care and for=
 your useful reply. Enabling the 
> property "setShouldFetchBodyRule" which=
 is under "FetchHTTP" processor 
> will prevent downloading a large file in=
 case of its size is written in 
> HTTP header. If the file size is not inc=
luded in HTTP header, then what 
> is the suitable solution to prevent down=
loading large files? Thanks again.
> 
> Mohamed Elsayed
> Bibliotheca Alexa=
ndrina
> 
> On 12/01/2010 03:03 PM, kristsi25 wrote:
> >
> >
> >
> > The No=
tExceedsDocumentLengthTresholdDecideRule can not be used in the 
> > scope =
rules as you have configured. Scope rules are applied prior to 
> > any net=
work activity and the size of the document is unknown at that 
> > time. On=
ly rules relating to the actual URL itself can be applied in 
> > scope rul=
es.
> >
> > The NotExceedsDocumentLengthTresholdDecideRule should be used t=
o 
> > influence the behavior of processors. For each processor it is 
> > =
possible to set a shouldProcessDecideRule attribute. If you merely 
> > wis=
h to avoid storing such long files, you could apply the filter to 
> > the =
(W)ARCWriterProcessor.
> >
> > If you wish to avoid downloading large files=
, you will need to apply 
> > the setShouldFetchBodyRule to the FetchHTTP p=
rocessor and make sure 
> > your NotExceedsDocumentLengthTresholdDecideRule=
 is set to use header 
> > length. This will cause the FetchHTTP processor =
to run the decide rule 
> > after fetching the HTTP header (which hopefully=
 contains an accurate 
> > content-length value) and will not download the =
actual file if it is 
> > too large.
> >
> > - Kris
> >
